conclusion: The problem involves finding the potential difference U_{ab} between points a and b on a conductor rod rotating in a uniform magnetic field.
The conductor rod ab has a length of 4L and rotates around point O, which is very close to end a.
The rod rotates at a constant angular velocity ω about an axis perpendicular to the paper.
There is a uniform magnetic field with magnetic induction intensity B, perpendicular to the plane of rotation.
The potential difference U_{ab} will be equal to the induced EMF between points a and b.
The EMF induced in a conductor moving in a magnetic field is given by the motional EMF formula: E = ∫(v × B) · dl.

premise: The rod rotates around an axis through O, perpendicular to the paper, so the axis of rotation is along the z-axis.
conclusion: The angular velocity ω is in the +z direction (counterclockwise rotation in the plane).

premise: The magnetic field B is uniform and perpendicular to the plane of rotation, so B = B z (out of the paper).
conclusion: The velocity of the rod is perpendicular to B, inducing an EMF along the rod.

premise: For a point at a distance r from O, the linear velocity due to rotation is v = ω r.
conclusion: At r = 0 (point a), v = 0. At r = 4L (point b), v = 4ω L.

premise: The velocity v = ω r y for a point at distance r.
conclusion: The cross product v × B = -ω r B x.

premise: The differential length element along the rod is dl = dr x.
The induced EMF is the integral from a (r = 0) to b (r = 4L): E = ∫(v × B) · dl = ∫(-ω r B) dr.
The magnitude of the EMF is |E| = 8 ω B L^2.
conclusion: The potential difference U_{ab} = |E| = 8 ω B L^2.
